BizTalk Server 2004 – Hosts & Host Instances

Posted by jefflynch on February 22, 2005

If you’ve been following my posts for the past few months, you know that I’m a big fan of Alan Smith’s BizTalk Modular Deployment approach. One of the keys to this approach is using separate hosts and host instances (I’ll explain the difference in a minute) for each modular “integration” you develop.


To quote Alan… “When an application is deployed or updated, it’s often required to restart the BizTalk host instance that the application runs in, to ensure the DLLs are reloaded correctly. If all the orchestrations in the hub were running in the same host instance, this would interrupt the processing of all the business processes. If a separate host is created for each module, that host instance can be restarted without affecting any other business processes.”


First a few definitions: “A BizTalk Host is a logical set of zero or more BizTalk runtime processes in which you deploy items such as adapter handlers, receive locations (including pipelines), and orchestrations. A Host Instance is the place where the message processing, receiving, and transmitting occurs. You install a host instance on each Microsoft® BizTalk® Server computer that has one or more hosts mapped to that server.”


Working Hint #1: You must be a member of the BizTalk Administrators Windows Group and be a SQL Server Administrator to create hosts, modify host properties, and delete hosts.


To Create a New Host:


Start the BizTalk Administration Console and expand the Microsoft BizTalk Server 2004 (Local) node as shown in Figure 1 below.


 Figure 1: The BizTalk Administrator Console


Right-click Hosts, select New and then select Host as shown in Figure 2 below.


 Figure 2: Adding a new Host


In the New Host dialog type the name of the new host. It helps to use a name associated with your modular integration as shown in Figure 3. Next type the name of the local or domain group for the host, then select the type of host (in-process or isolated) and finally select the host tracking check box.


 Figure 3: Setting the Host properties

OK, we’re all done right? Well not quite yet. We’ve created our new host but we need to install an instance of that host on the server that will do the actual work. Remember, the Host is only a logical container. The Host Instance is the physical (real) container. The next step is to install the Host Instance on one of our BizTalk Server computers.


To Install a Host Instance:


Right-click on the Host you just created, click New and then select Instance as shown in Figure 4 below.


 Figure 4: Installing a New Host Instance

In the Add Host Instances dialog box select the physical server you want the Host Instance to run on as shown in Figure 5.


 Figure 5: Selecting the server to run on

In the Provide Account Information dialog box, type the login and password of the service account this Host Instance will run under as shown in Figure 6.


 Figure 6: Service Account Login

Assuming everything goes correctly, you now have a new Host and Host Instance ready to go as shown in Figure 7.


Figure 7: Your new Host and Host Instance!
